pull.title: [API BREAK] Use a nonce-generation function instead of a nonce

repo.name: secp256k1
repo.description: Optimized C library for EC operations on curve secp256k1

repo.name: secp256k1
repo.description: Optimized C library for EC operations on curve secp256k1

events.body: Change looks reasonable to me. Seems safer in any case.
Perhaps the comment for the nonce function should say "The resulting output MUST be uniformly distributed. Even small biases can compromises the security of the private key."
Would it be better to bundle the callback args into a struct?

I mean that secp256k1_nonce_function_t could just have a single struct\* parameter, which struct would contain nonce32, msg32, key32, attempt, data. I'm just thinking that if later we discover we want to pass more parameters, they could be added to the struct without a breaking change to the API.
I don't consider the API stable at this point anyway.

events.message: [API BREAK] Use a nonce-generation function instead of a nonce

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -77,40 +77,63 @@ SECP256K1_WARN_UNUSED_RESULT int secp256k1_ecdsa_verify(
   int pubkeylen
 ) SECP256K1_ARG_NONNULL(1) SECP256K1_ARG_NONNULL(2) SECP256K1_ARG_NONNULL(4);
 
+/** A pointer to a function to deterministically generate a nonce.
+ * Returns: 1 if a nonce was succesfully generated. 0 will cause signing to fail.
+ * In:      msg32:     the 32-byte message hash being verified (will not be NULL)
+ *          key32:     pointer to a 32-byte secret key (will not be NULL)
+ *          attempt:   how many iterations we have tried to find a nonce.
+ *                     This will almost always be 0.
+ *          data:      Arbitrary data pointer that is passed through.
+ * Out:     nonce32:   pointer to a 32-byte array to be filled by the function.
+ * Except for test cases, this function should compute some cryptographic hash of
+ * the message, the key and the attempt. It is advised to use RFC6979.
+ */
+typedef int (*secp256k1_nonce_function_t)(
+  unsigned char *nonce32,
+  const unsigned char *msg32,
+  const unsigned char *key32,
+  unsigned int attempt,
+  const void* data
comments.body: nit: inconsistency in \* placement everywhere for the callback data.

@@ -77,40 +77,63 @@ SECP256K1_WARN_UNUSED_RESULT int secp256k1_ecdsa_verify(

 ) SECP256K1_ARG_NONNULL(1) SECP256K1_ARG_NONNULL(2) SECP256K1_ARG_NONNULL(4);
 
+/** A pointer to a function to deterministically generate a nonce.
+ * Returns: 1 if a nonce was succesfully generated. 0 will cause signing to fail.
+ * In:      msg32:     the 32-byte message hash being verified (will not be NULL)

+ * Out:     nonce32:   pointer to a 32-byte array to be filled by the function.
+ * Except for test cases, this function should compute some cryptographic hash of
+ * the message, the key and the attempt. It is advised to use RFC6979.
+ */

+  unsigned char *nonce32,
+  const unsigned char *msg32,
+  const unsigned char *key32,
+  unsigned int attempt,
+  const void* data

comments.body: nit: don't see where this dependency was introduced
Fixed, It was introduced in an earlier edit that was changed again.

+/** A pointer to a function to deterministically generate a nonce.

comments.body: Maybe there should be an explicit mention that if attempt is non-zero it implies a different nonce is required.
